sentence: In the U.S, it is Thanksgiving week, and that normally means a period of calm for the stock market.
Earnings season is drawing to a close, and as traders take time off and prepare for the holiday, volume and volatility are usually low with a slight upward bias in anticipation of Black Friday.
That may not be the case this year.
Volume will probably still be down, but as anyone who has tried to close out a position just before an earnings announcement or data release will tell you, that doesn’t always mean calm markets.
Lack of volume also means a lack of liquidity, and that can exaggerate moves prompted by worry, speculation, or actual hard news.
There will be no shortage of any of those things this week.
The worry comes from a subject that has consumed the market for some time, taxes.
Stocks were given a boost last week when the House passed its bill, but that was never really in doubt.

The Republicans have a massive majority in the lower chamber, and while their version of tax reform wasn’t without controversy and garnered some opposition among a few Republicans, it never looked in danger.

The problem this week is that there are always a few who have problems with a bill, or more cynically see any major bill as an opportunity to exercise power and raise their profile, and a few is more than enough to cast doubt on the progress of the Senate bill.
The Republicans can only afford to lose two Senators if the bill is to pass, and around half a dozen have already expressed misgivings.
Given how much has been staked on tax cuts, and corporate tax cuts in particular, even just politicians’ normal brinkmanship and jockeying for position will be enough to cause plenty of worry.

The speculation will revolve around two separate but closely related things, Jerome Powell’s upcoming Senate confirmation hearing and the approach of a Fed meeting at which rates are expected to be raised.

Powell is expected to be confirmed, but in the current partisan environment he will face some hostile questioning, which always opens up the possibility of him saying something unexpected under pressure.
That could come on the subject of a long-anticipated December hike or the path of rate hikes after that.

Powell’s politics may make him reluctant to do or say anything that makes the market nervous, but his voting record on the Fed board over the last few years indicates that he believes that the current tightening is justified.

If there is any hint of continued hikes it will have an exaggerated effect given the attention being given to the wobble in high yield and the fact that corporate debt is now over 45% of GDP, the highest since 2007.
As for hard data, that comes on two fronts.
The first will be the remaining earnings releases schedule for this week.
Earnings have generally been supportive of stocks, with nearly three quarters of S&P 500 companies reporting higher than expected EPS, but there have still been some high-profile misses.
This week we will hear from both Hewlett Packard businesses, HPE and HPQ, as well as Salesforce (CRM), John Deere (DE) and Lowe's (LOW).
The second is economic data, which will include existing home sales and consumer sentiment numbers, as well as the release of the minutes from the last FOMC meeting.
There are, then, plenty of things that could cause disruption in this shortened holiday week.

Many of them, particularly taxes and interest rates, could have a lasting impact and given the nervousness around current valuations and the overall political situation, they could lead to this being anything but the usual quiet Thanksgiving week.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
